title: U.S. Resisted the Metric System -- or Did It?
text:
St. Johns, Mich.

---

I'm 5 feet 11 inches tall, weigh 200 pounds and I set the oven to 400 degrees Fahrenheit. But my body temperature is 36 degrees Celsius, I drive 100 kilometers an hour on the highway and C$1.25 for a liter of gas is a good deal here in Canada. My favorite deli order is 200 grams of Black Forest ham, but at McDonald's it's a Quarter Pounder. The weirdest one to me -- and I may be alone on this -- is that I measure temperature outside in Celsius but inside in Fahrenheit: "It's going down to 10 degrees tonight. Better turn the heat up to 73."

If Canada is metric-ish, the U.S. is imperial-ish. Drugs are bought in grams and kilos, and the most common bullet is the 9 millimeter. In Canada, it's the 30-ought-6 rifle shell, which is 0.3 of an inch in diameter. Whatever the measure, the size is the same.

Whether in metric or imperial, let's agree that Prof. Block's connection between measurements, government control and a 45-year slow play by Canada to get the U.S. to convert to the metric system can only be measured as a stretch.

Matt Roncadin

Stouffville, Ontario
